prompt: Mark told Pete many lies about himself, which Pete included in his book. He should have been more skeptical.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Pete".  In the sentence, "He" is the subject of the verb "should have been more skeptical", which is in the passive voice. The subject of the sentence is the one who should have done something (been more skeptical), and in this case, it is Pete, the person who included Mark's lies in his book. Mark is the one who told the lies, but it is Pete who is being advised to have been more skeptical.

prompt: The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them. They are very happy to have them back, but they scold them just the same because they ran away.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "mothers"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "them" does not refer to "mothers". The sentence states that the mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them, which implies that "them" refers to Arthur and Celeste.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain, promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mr. Singer"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "He" does not refer to "Mr. Singer". The sentence structure and context suggest that "He" refers to Mark, who is described as being "close to Mr. Singer's heels".  The sentence starts with "Mark was close to Mr. Singer's heels", which establishes that Mark is physically close to Mr. Singer. The verb "heard" in the next clause implies that Mark is the one who heard Mr. Singer calling for the captain, which further supports the conclusion that "He" refers to Mark.

prompt: The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice; but at last he just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge. He wanted me to help him out, but I hope you will excuse me, sir, I did not feel inclined to do so.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "young gentleman"? Explain your choice.
response: A clever question!  After analyzing the sentence, I believe "He" refers to the pony, not the young gentleman. Here's why:  * The sentence starts by describing the pony's behavior, saying "The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice..." This suggests that "He" is likely referring to the pony. * The phrase "He just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge" implies that the pony is the one performing the action, and the young gentleman is the one being affected by it. * The sentence then says "He wanted me to help him out", which is a pronoun reference that is likely referring back to the pony, as it is the one that needs help.  So, while the young gentleman is the one who is affected by the pony's behavior, "He" in this sentence is indeed referring to the pony.

prompt: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "the cup"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "it" refers to "the cup". This is because the sentence is describing the action of pouring water from the bottle into the cup, and "it" is the direct object of the verb "was full". The sentence is saying that the cup was full of water after the pouring action was completed.

prompt: Dan had to stop Bill from toying with the injured bird. He is very compassionate.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Dan"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Dan".  The sentence structure is "Dan had to stop Bill from toying with the injured bird", which means that Dan is the one who took action to prevent Bill from doing something. The pronoun "He" is then used to refer back to Dan, indicating that Dan is the one who is compassionate and stopped Bill from toying with the bird.

prompt: Sam Goodman 's biography of the Spartan general Xenophanes conveys a vivid sense of the difficulties he faced in his childhood.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Goodman"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Goodman". The sentence is talking about Xenophanes, a Spartan general, and "he" refers to Xenophanes, indicating that the biography by Sam Goodman is about Xenophanes' childhood.

prompt: Pam's parents came home and found her having sex with her boyfriend, Paul. They were furious about it.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "Pam's parents"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "they" does not refer to "Pam's parents". The word "they" is used to refer to "Pam's parents" in the preceding clause "Pam's parents came home and found her having sex with her boyfriend, Paul", but in the following clause "They were furious about it", "they" is used to refer to Pam's parents, not Pam.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education, but now Charlie acts as though it never happened. He is very hurt.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "He" does not refer to "Bob".  The sentence states "Charlie acts as though it never happened", which implies that "it" refers to Charlie's college education being paid for by Bob. Therefore, "He" must refer to Charlie.

prompt: Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share his toy.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Toby"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "his" does not refer to "Toby". "His" is a possessive adjective modifying the noun "toy", indicating that the toy belongs to Billy.

prompt: Emma did not pass the ball to Janie although she was open.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Janie"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "she" does not refer to "Janie".  The sentence says "Emma did not pass the ball to Janie", which means that Emma is the one who did not pass the ball. Therefore, "she" refers to Emma, not Janie.

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one below it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "it" does not refer to "Sam's drawing".  The pronoun "it" is referring to the phrase "Tina's drawing" which is implied to be the one that is being hung below Sam's drawing. The sentence is saying that Sam's drawing looked better with another drawing (Tina's) below it.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education, but now Charlie acts as though it never happened. He is very ungrateful.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "He" refers to "Charlie". The sentence structure is:  "Bob paid for Charlie's college education, but now Charlie acts as though it never happened. He is very ungrateful."  The phrase "but now Charlie" indicates that the subject of the sentence is changing from "Bob" to "Charlie". The pronoun "He" is used to refer back to "Charlie", indicating that it is Charlie who is acting ungrateful.

prompt: The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to answer it.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the lawyer"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "the lawyer". The sentence states "the lawyer asked the witness a question", so the subject of the sentence is "the lawyer", and "he" is the subject of the clause "he was reluctant to answer it". Therefore, "he" refers to the witness, not the lawyer.

prompt: Sam took French classes from Adam , because he was eager to speak it fluently.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Sam"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "Sam".  The subject of the sentence is "Sam", and the sentence is describing Sam's actions, specifically that he took French classes from Adam. The pronoun "he" is a possessive pronoun that refers back to the subject "Sam", indicating that the action of taking French classes belongs to Sam.

prompt: Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't convince him.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Mark". The subject of the sentence is "Sid", who is the one who explained his theory. "He" is the object of the sentence, referring back to Sid, indicating that Sid was the one who couldn't convince Mark.

prompt: The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they advocated violence.  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "The demonstrators"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "they" refers to "the demonstrators".  In this sentence, the subject of the sentence is "the city councilmen", and the verb is "refused". The phrase "a permit" is an object of the verb "refused". The phrase "because they advocated violence" is a subordinate clause, and "they" is the subject of this clause. Since the demonstrators are the ones who advocated violence, it is logical to conclude that "they" refers to the demonstrators.

prompt: When Tommy dropped his ice cream, Timmy giggled, so father gave him a sympathetic look.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Timmy"? Explain your choice.
response: A classic ambiguity!  At first glance, it seems like "him" should refer to "Timmy", as it's the one who giggled. However, the sentence structure and word order suggest that "him" actually refers to "Tommy", the one who dropped the ice cream.  The sentence is structured as "When X happened, Y did Z, so Z did A". In this case, "When Tommy dropped his ice cream" is the condition, "Timmy giggled" is the action, and "father gave him a sympathetic look" is the consequence. The subject of the sentence is the one who receives the action (the look), which is "him", which logically refers to Tommy, the one who dropped the ice cream.  So, while it's tempting to assume "him" refers to Timmy, the context and sentence structure indicate that it actually refers to Tommy.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, in the sentence "he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.", "he" refers to "the master".  The pronoun "he" is used to refer back to the subject "the master", which is the one who was previously described as being angry. The sentence is describing the master's actions, and "he" is used to indicate that the master is the one who did not give Bill any more punishment, set him up on a stool, and made the statement about not going out to play.

prompt: The journalists interviewed the stars of the new movie. They were very cooperative, so the interview lasted for a long time.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "The journalists"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "They" refers to "The journalists". In the sentence, "They" is the subject of the sentence, and it is performing the action described by the verb "interviewed". Since "The journalists" is the only entity that could be performing the action of interviewing, it is the most likely antecedent for the pronoun "They".

prompt: Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had given.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "she" does not refer to "Susan". "She" refers to "Joan", the subject of the sentence. The sentence is structured as "Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had given", where "she" is the object of the verb "made sure to thank", referring back to "Joan".

prompt: In the storm, the tree fell down and crashed through the roof of my house. Now, I have to get it repaired.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The roof"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "it" does not refer to "the roof". The sentence is saying that the tree fell down and crashed through the roof of my house, and then the speaker has to get something repaired. The subject of the sentence is the tree, so "it" is referring back to the tree. The tree fell down and crashed through the roof, causing damage, and now the speaker has to get the resulting damage repaired.

prompt: Beth didn't get angry with Sally , who had cut her off, because she stopped and counted to ten.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Beth"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "she" refers to "Beth".  The sentence states "Beth didn't get angry with Sally", so it is clear that "she" is referring to Beth.

prompt: The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to repeat it.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the lawyer"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "the lawyer".  The subject of the sentence is "the witness", and the sentence is describing the witness's reluctance to repeat the question. The pronoun "he" is a possessive pronoun, referring back to the witness ("his reluctance"). The lawyer is the one who asked the question, but the sentence is not describing the lawyer's reluctance, but rather the witness's.  So, the correct interpretation is that "he" refers to the witness, not the lawyer.

prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. His old coachman is getting feeble, and he wants a man to work with him and get into his ways, who would be able, when the old man was pensioned off, to step into his place  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "new groom"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "his" does not refer to "new groom".  In the sentence, "his" refers to "coachman". The phrase "his business" is a possessive phrase, indicating that the coachman's business is being referred to. The coachman is getting feeble, and Sir Clifford wants a new groom who knows the coachman's business, i.e., the skills and ways of the coachman.

prompt: Since it was raining, I carried the newspaper over my backpack to keep it dry.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The newspaper"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "it" does not refer to "the newspaper". Instead, "it" refers to the rain.  The sentence can be broken down as follows:  * "Since it was raining" - This clause sets the condition for the subsequent action. * "I carried the newspaper over my backpack to keep it dry." - The action of carrying the newspaper is done because of the rain.  So, "it" in the sentence refers to the rain, not the newspaper.

prompt: If the con artist has succeeded in fooling Sam , he would have gotten a lot of money.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "The con artist"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to the con artist. The pronoun "he" is used as the subject of the sentence, and it is the one who would have gotten a lot of money if the con artist succeeded in fooling Sam. The sentence is structured as a conditional sentence, where "if" introduces a condition (the con artist succeeding in fooling Sam), and the main clause describes the result of that condition (the con artist getting a lot of money).

prompt: The boy continued to whip the pony , and eventually the pony threw him over. John laughed out quite loud. "Served him right," he said.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "pony"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "him" does not refer to "pony".  In the sentence, "him" is the object of the verb "served", and it refers back to "the boy". The sentence is saying that the boy got what he deserved, i.e., being thrown off the pony.  The use of "him" instead of "the boy" is an example of a pronoun referring back to a noun that was previously mentioned, which is a common grammatical construction in English.

prompt: I put the cake away in the refrigerator . It has a lot of leftovers in it.  In the sentence above, does "It" refer to "The cake"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "It" refers to "the refrigerator".  The reason is that the subject of the sentence is "I", and "put the cake away in the refrigerator" is the action being performed by "I". The phrase "in the refrigerator" is a prepositional phrase that modifies the verb "put", indicating the location where the cake is being placed. Therefore, "it" cannot refer to the cake, as the cake is the object being acted upon, not the subject performing the action.

prompt: The fish ate the worm . It was tasty.  In the sentence above, does "It" refer to "The worm"? Explain your choice.
response: A classic case of ambiguity!  In this sentence, "It" can actually refer to either "The fish" or "The worm". Both readings are grammatically possible and make sense in different ways.  If "It" refers to "The worm", then the sentence means that the worm was eaten by the fish and it was tasty.  If "It" refers to "The fish", then the sentence means that the fish ate the worm, and the fish itself was tasty (which is an unusual interpretation, but still grammatically correct!).  In this case, the sentence is ambiguous, and the reader needs more context to disambiguate the reference.

prompt: Babar wonders how he can get new clothing. Luckily, a very rich old man who has always been fond of little elephants understands right away that he is longing for a fine suit. As he likes to make people happy, he gives him his wallet.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Babar"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" in the sentence refers to the rich old man. The sentence states "a very rich old man... understands right away that Babar is longing for a fine suit", so it is clear that the rich old man is the one who understands Babar's longing. The pronoun "he" in the sentence "As he likes to make people happy, he gives him his wallet" refers back to the rich old man, indicating that he is the one who gives Babar his wallet.

prompt: The actress used to be named Terpsichore , but she changed it to Tina a few years ago, because she figured it was easier to pronounce.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Terpsichore"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "it" does not refer to "Terpsichore". The pronoun "it" is likely referring to "the name Terpsichore", which is a noun phrase. The sentence is saying that the actress changed the name "Terpsichore" to "Tina" because she thought it (the name) was easier to pronounce.

prompt: So Mark slept. It was daylight when he woke with Warren 's hand upon his shoulder.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Warren"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "his" does refer to "Warren". The phrase "Warren's hand" is a possessive phrase indicating that Warren is the one whose hand is on Mark's shoulder. The pronoun "his" is used to indicate that the hand belongs to Warren.

prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His hands"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "them" refers to "his hands". The pronoun "them" is the object of the preposition "with", and it is the direct object of the verb "covered". The verb "covered" takes a direct object, which is the thing that is being covered, which in this case is "his hands".

prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. His old coachman is getting feeble, and he wants a man to work with him and get into his ways, who would be able, when the old man was pensioned off, to step into his place  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "old coachman"? Explain your choice.
response: The pronoun "his" does not refer to "old coachman". Instead, it refers to "Sir Clifford".  The sentence structure suggests that "his" is possessive, indicating that Sir Clifford is the one who has a coachman, and that coachman is getting feeble. The phrase "his old coachman" is a noun phrase modifying the verb "is getting feeble", indicating that the coachman belongs to Sir Clifford.  If "his" were to refer to "old coachman", the sentence would imply that the old coachman has an old coachman, which doesn't make sense in the context.  So, the correct interpretation is that "his" refers to Sir Clifford, indicating that Sir Clifford's coachman is getting feeble.

prompt: Joe paid the detective after he delivered the final report on the case.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Joe"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Joe".  In the sentence, "he" refers to the detective. The subject of the sentence is "Joe", who is the one paying the detective, and "he" is the object of the verb "paid", referring back to the detective.

prompt: As Andrea in the crop duster passed over Susan , she could see the landing strip.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "she" does not refer to "Susan". "She" refers to "Andrea", as it is Andrea who is in the crop duster and can see the landing strip.

prompt: Frank was upset with Tom because the toaster he had bought from him didn't work.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Tom"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Tom".  In the sentence, "he" is likely referring to Frank, the subject of the sentence. The sentence is describing Frank's emotions and actions, and "he" is used as the object of the verb "was upset with".  The phrase "the toaster he had bought from him" is a subordinate clause that describes the context of the toaster, and "him" is the object of the preposition "from". "Him" refers back to Tom, the one who sold the toaster to Frank.

prompt: Lily spoke to Donna , breaking her silence.  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "Donna"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "her" refers to "Donna".  The phrase "breaking her silence" is a idiomatic expression that means to speak after a long period of not speaking, often due to some kind of constraint or reluctance. In this case, "her" is a possessive pronoun referring back to Donna, indicating that Donna was the one who had been silent and is now speaking to Lily.

prompt: The cat was lying by the mouse hole waiting for the mouse , but it was too cautious.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The cat"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "it" refers to "the mouse".  The reason is that the sentence is describing the mouse's behavior, saying that the mouse was "too cautious". The pronoun "it" is being used as a reflexive pronoun, referring back to the subject "the mouse". The sentence is saying that the mouse was too cautious to come out of its hole, not the cat.

prompt: Equally swoon-worthy is C.K. Dexter Haven , a pallid young dandy holding a jade-handled walking stick, with a poodle asleep at his feet  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Haven"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "his" refers to "Haven". The phrase "with a poodle asleep at his feet" is describing C.K. Dexter Haven, the subject of the sentence. The pronoun "his" is used to indicate possession, meaning the poodle belongs to Haven.

prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. His old coachman is getting feeble, and he wants a man to work with him and get into his ways, who would be able, when the old man was pensioned off, to step into his place.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Sir Clifford"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "his" does not refer to "Sir Clifford".   The phrase "his old coachman" suggests that "his" refers to the coachman's old coachman, indicating possession. It is the coachman who is getting feeble, so "his" is a possessive pronoun indicating that the coachman owns the old coachman.  If "his" referred to Sir Clifford, it would be "his old coach", which would imply that Sir Clifford has an old coach, which is not the intended meaning.

prompt: The fish ate the worm . It was tasty.  In the sentence above, does "It" refer to "The fish"? Explain your choice.
response: A classic example of a pronoun ambiguity!  In this sentence, "It" can actually refer to either "The fish" or "The worm". This is because both "The fish" and "The worm" are nouns that can be the subject of the sentence, and the pronoun "It" is not explicitly linked to either one through a clear antecedent.  However, in this specific sentence, the most likely interpretation is that "It" refers to "The worm". This is because the sentence is describing the action of the fish eating the worm, and the pronoun "It" is more closely associated with the object being eaten (the worm) than the subject doing the eating (the fish).  In other words, the sentence is saying "The fish ate something, and that something was the worm, which was tasty". The pronoun "It" is simply a convenient way to refer back to the worm without repeating the noun.  Of course, without more context, it's impossible to say for certain which interpretation is correct, but based on the sentence structure and the meaning of the sentence, I believe "It" is most likely referring to "The worm".

prompt: Lionel is holding captive a scientist, Dr. Vardi , who has invented a device that turns animals invisible; Lionel plans to use it on Geoffrey and send him to steal nuclear material from an army vault.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Lionel"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "him" does not refer to "Lionel".   In the sentence, "him" refers to "Geoffrey", as the verb "send" is in the infinitive phrase "to send him", and the intended recipient of the action is Geoffrey, not Lionel. Lionel is the one holding the scientist and planning to use the device on Geoffrey.

prompt: The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they feared violence.  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "The city councilmen"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "they" is not a pronoun that refers to "The city councilmen". The subject of the sentence is "The city councilmen", and they are the ones who refused the demonstrators a permit.  The pronoun "they" is actually referring to "the demonstrators", which is the object of the verb "refused". The sentence implies that the city councilmen refused to give the permit to the demonstrators, not that the city councilmen themselves are the ones who would be involved in violence.  So, the correct interpretation is that "they" is a pronoun that refers back to "the demonstrators", not "The city councilmen".

prompt: Frank felt vindicated when his longtime rival Bill revealed that he was the winner of the competition.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Bill".  The sentence says "Frank felt vindicated when his longtime rival Bill revealed that he was the winner of the competition." The word "he" is the subject of the verb "was", and it refers to Frank, not Bill. Frank is the one who felt vindicated, and the sentence is saying that he was vindicated because Bill revealed that Frank was the winner of the competition.

prompt: Bob collapsed on the sidewalk. Soon he saw Carl coming to help. He was very concerned.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "He" does not refer to "Bob".  In the sentence, "He" refers to "Carl", because Carl is the one who is coming to help. The pronoun "He" is used to refer back to Carl, who is the subject of the sentence "He was very concerned".

prompt: Dan took the rear seat while Bill claimed the front because his "Dibs!" was slow.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.
response: A clever question!  In this sentence, "his" does indeed refer to "Bill". The phrase "his 'Dibs!' was slow" is a possessive phrase, indicating that the "Dibs!" being referred to belongs to Bill. The word "his" is used to indicate possession, showing that the "Dibs!" in question is Bill's.  So, the sentence can be paraphrased as: "Bill claimed the front seat because his (Bill's) 'Dibs!' was slow."

prompt: Susan knows all about Ann 's personal problems because she is nosy.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Susan"? Explain your choice.
response: A classic grammar question!  In this sentence, "she" does not necessarily refer to "Susan". The pronoun "she" is a reflexive pronoun that can refer back to a noun or pronoun that has already been mentioned in the sentence. In this case, "she" could also refer to "Ann", as it is Ann's personal problems that are being discussed.  So, the sentence could be interpreted as: "Susan knows all about Ann's personal problems because Ann is nosy." In this interpretation, "she" refers to Ann, who is the one who is nosy.  However, if we want to emphasize that Susan is the one who is nosy, we could rephrase the sentence to: "Susan is nosy, which is why she knows all about Ann's personal problems." In this case, "she" clearly refers to Susan.

prompt: Pete envies Martin because he is very successful.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Pete"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "he" refers to "Pete". This is because the sentence is in the passive voice, where the subject "Pete" is the one doing the envying, and "he" is the object of the verb "envies". The sentence can be rewritten in the active voice to make it clearer: "Pete envies Martin because Martin is very successful."

prompt: Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share his toy.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Billy"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "his" does not refer to "Billy".  In the sentence, "his" is a possessive adjective modifying the noun "toy", indicating that the toy belongs to Toby. The sentence is saying that Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share a toy that belongs to Toby, not Billy.

prompt: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "the bottle"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "it" does not refer to "the bottle". The subject of the sentence is "water", which is the thing being poured. The phrase "from the bottle" is a prepositional phrase modifying the verb "poured", indicating the source of the water. The pronoun "it" refers to "the cup", which is the thing being filled.

prompt: I used an old rag to clean the knife , and then I put it in the trash.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The knife"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "it" refers to "the knife".  The sentence structure is: "I used an old rag to clean the knife, and then I put [something] in the trash." The phrase "and then I put" is a dependent clause that describes the action that follows the main action of cleaning the knife. The pronoun "it" is used to refer back to the subject of the main clause, which is "the knife".

prompt: John hired Bill to take care of him .  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "John hired Bill to take care of him", "him" is actually referring to John, not Bill.  This is because the verb "to take care of" is a verb phrase that typically takes an object, and the object is the person or thing being taken care of. In this sentence, the object is John, who is the one being taken care of by Bill.  The pronoun "him" is the object of the preposition "of", and it refers back to the subject "John", indicating that John is the one being taken care of.  So, the correct interpretation is that John is the one being taken care of, and Bill is the one doing the taking care of.

prompt: Jane knocked on the door, and Susan answered it. She invited her to come out.  In the sentence above, does "She" refer to "Jane"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The journalists interviewed the stars of the new movie. They were very persistent, so the interview lasted for a long time.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "The journalists"? Explain your choice.

prompt: As Ollie carried Tommy up the long winding steps, his legs ached.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Ollie"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Carol believed that Rebecca regretted that she had stolen the watch.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Rebecca"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education. He is very generous.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Charlie"? Explain your choice.

prompt: All the buttons up the back of Dora 's plaid dress were buttoned outside-in. Maude should have thought to button her up; but no, she had left poor little Dora to do the best she could, alone.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Dora"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The table was piled high with food , and on the floor beside it there were crocks, baskets, and a five-quart pail of milk.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "floor"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. prompt: The man lifted the boy onto his shoulders.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "The boy"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Peter"? Explain your choice.

The pronoun "his" is a possessive pronoun, indicating that the food belongs to the captain, not Peter. The sentence is using a pronoun to refer back to the noun "captain", which is the one who ate the food in question.  So, the correct interpretation is that the sentence is questioning whether the cook might have put something in the captain's food, not Peter's food.

prompt: The signs over the shops' doors had pictures that indicated what work was done inside. Although more and more people were learning how to read, each artisan still had signs, not wishing to lose a possible patron merely because he happened to be illiterate.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "patron"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "patron".  In the sentence, "he" is actually referring back to "artisan", which is the subject of the sentence. The sentence is saying that each artisan (a person who does a specific trade or craft) still has a sign outside their shop, not wanting to lose a possible customer (patron) because the customer is illiterate.

prompt: Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't available.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "George"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one above it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.
response: A nice question!  In this sentence, "it" is actually referring to "Tina's drawing", not "Sam's drawing".  The sentence is saying that Sam's drawing was hung above Tina's drawing, and it (i.e., Tina's drawing) looked much better with another one above it.  The pronoun "it" is a reflexive pronoun that refers back to the noun "drawing" that was mentioned earlier in the sentence, which is Tina's drawing.

prompt: The table won't fit through the doorway because it is too wide.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The table"? Explain your choice.
response: A classic example of a pronoun ambiguity!  In this sentence, "it" can indeed refer to either "the table" or "the doorway". However, the most likely interpretation is that "it" refers to "the table".  The reason is that the sentence is describing a problem with the table, specifically that it is too wide to fit through the doorway. This implies that the table is the entity that is causing the issue, rather than the doorway. If the doorway were too narrow, it would be more likely to say "the doorway is too small" rather than "it is too small".  Additionally, the sentence structure and word order also support the interpretation that "it" refers to the table. The sentence is in the passive voice, with "the table" as the subject, and "is too wide" as the predicate. This makes it more natural to assume that "it" is referring to the table.  So, while it's possible to interpret "it" as referring to the doorway, the more likely and natural interpretation is that "it" refers to the table.

prompt: Emma Emma's mother had died long ago, and her education had been managed by an excellent woman as governess.  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "Emma's mother"? Explain your choice.

The sentence is describing Emma's situation and education, so "her" is referring back to Emma as the subject of the sentence.

prompt: Bill passed the gameboy to John because his turn was next.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "John"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Of one thing Mark was sure. Harry knew much less than he did.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Harry"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "the captain"? Explain your choice.

In this case, the sentence is suggesting that Peter might be responsible for the captain's illness, and that Peter might have bribed the cook to put something in the captain's food. Therefore, "his" is referring back to the captain, indicating that the food belongs to him.

prompt: What about the time you cut up tulip bulbs in the hamburgers because you thought they were onions?  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "hamburgers"? Explain your choice.
response: A humorous anecdote!  In this sentence, "they" does not refer to "hamburgers". The pronoun "they" is likely referring to the tulip bulbs.  Here's why:  * The sentence is describing an action of cutting up something, which is typically done to an ingredient, not a food item like a hamburger. * The phrase "because you thought they were onions" implies that "they" were mistaken for something else, which would be the tulip bulbs, not the hamburgers. * Hamburgers are not typically cut up into small pieces before being cooked, unlike onions, which are often finely chopped or minced.  So, in this sentence, "they" is likely referring to the tulip bulbs, which were mistakenly believed to be onions and were cut up accordingly!

prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His eyes"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "them" refers to "his eyes". The sentence is using a reflexive pronoun "them" to refer back to the direct object "his eyes". This is a common grammatical construction in English, where a reflexive pronoun is used to refer back to a noun or pronoun that is the object of the action described in the sentence.  In this case, "his eyes" is the direct object of the verb "covered", and "them" is the reflexive pronoun that refers back to "his eyes". This means that the sentence is saying that Fred covered his eyes with his own eyes, which is a logical and grammatically correct construction.

prompt: Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't understand him.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Sid"? Explain your choice.

The pronoun "he" in the second part of the sentence is referring to Mark, indicating that Mark is the one who couldn't understand.

prompt: Tom gave Ralph a lift to school so he wouldn't have to drive alone.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Ralph"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "Ralph". In the sentence, "he" refers to "Tom". The sentence is saying that Tom gave Ralph a lift to school, so "he" is the one performing the action of giving a lift.

prompt: When my parents died, I was not earning enough to keep myself or my crippled sister Nelly , and without our kind mistress , we would have gone to the poorhouse. Nelly calls her her angel and she has good right to do so. her  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "mistress"? Explain your choice.

It's a possessive pronoun indicating that Nelly is the one who calls the mistress an angel.  The sentence is saying that Nelly has good reason to call the mistress an angel because the mistress has been kind to them and helped them avoid poverty.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" does not refer to "the master".   In the sentence "I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill.", "him" refers to the master, not "he".   In the subsequent sentence, "he" refers to Bill, not the master. The sentence "but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind..." implies that the subject is Bill, not the master.

prompt: Ann asked Mary what time the library closes, because she had forgotten.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Mary"? Explain your choice.
